37868802.review:
Godot is a meticulously crafted piece of software.

Just imagine you want the latest dev build on ANY platform you are just two commands away. Git clone, scon platfrom=x11; and then run the fat binary.

It doesnt stop there the fat binary then crosscompiles your games from linux to the supported platforms.

In achieving this Godot places itself amoung a select few softwares of excellent quality; software such as Steam, Source engine (undoubtedly unfair comparissons as neither of these publish their code publicy), Firefox, Inkscape to name a few. It is a massive achievment.

It is very similar to unity in that it makes developing games accessible and takes care of many of the crossplatform hurdles.

37839126.review:
Genius software here. As a systems programmer I know how much content this engine has that would take ages to do from scratch. On that example alone, it shows just how crazy it is for this to be MIT licensed.

Godot 3.0 features a renderer similar to that of Unreal Engine 4's. You now may ask yourself, "Why not just use Unreal Engine 4?" Well, obviously because you know you can make a game in Godot, but you should be prepared for reality when you work with Unreal Engine 4.

As a pro game-dev tip: don't choose the engine for what you believe it can do. Choose the engine for what you *know* you can do.

Godot is free for all, and all for free.

36046459.review:
О Godot написано уже много хвалебных отзывов и они по праву им заслужены.

Godot можно смело назвать конструктором конструкторов. Это своего рода коробка с кубиками Lego, с той лишь разницей, что в Lego у вас много разных кубиков, но у всех жестко заданы свойства (размер, цвет итд). В Godot вы вольны создавать свои собственные «кубики» с какими угодно свойствами, параметрами. И самое главное, что из нескольких «кубиков» вы можете создавать новые, задавать им новые свойства, объединять или удалять, в общем всё как в настоящем программировании.

В Godot отличный скриптовый язык с большими возможностями, который очень похож по синтаксису на Python. Конечно, если вы раньше никогда не занимались программированием, вам будет немного труднее разобраться, возможно стоит начать с чего-то попроще, например с RPG Maker. Но если вы владеете хотя бы базовыми знаниями, то вы без труда (в большинстве случаев) быстро получите желаемый результат.

В системе достаточно много готовых «кубиков» таких как спрайт, полигональный объект, камера итд. Но кроме этого есть так называемые модули «физических свойств». Например можно «наделить» свой «кубик» физическими свойствами и он будет автоматически падать вниз, до тех пор пока не встретится с другим объектом, у которого указано, что он является поверхностью. Таким образом отпадает необходимость в проверке столкновений, система делает это автоматически.

Впрочем, если вы привыкли всё контролировать самостоятельно, в Godot отличная система сообщений (event) и вы можете обрабатывать ситуацию с помощью скриптов.

Понятно, что в таком коротком отзыве очень сложно перечислить все «плюшки» данного движка, так что настоятельно рекомендую к самостоятельному ознакомлению, тем более что он бесплатен. В комплекте идут отличные примеры, которые покажут минимальные возможности, а всё остальное ограниченно вашей фантазией.

p.s. Особенно радует, что после сборки проекта в готовую игру она занимает около 15 мегабайт (без учёта ресурсов), согласитесь это ещё один приятный момент в пользу Godot! ("\(๑˘◡˘๑)︵

35249914.review:
Long time user of Unity3d.  My initial impression of Godot Engine is good.  From what I've read the engine's scripting langauge (GDScript) is not good for things that demand performance (pathfinding, procedural generation, etc.), but it's great for gameplay logic or other things which do not require optimal performance.  Godot provides a module system which allows us to plug in and compile our own modules written in C++, and 3.0 will introduce C# and other features providing us with everything we need to work around GDScript's performance concerns.

The user interface is easy to navigate and easy on the eyes.

The software itself is lightweight and portable.

MIT license, no strings attached, no royalties.

I designed my Unity3d game's code to not be reliant on UnityEngine.  When Godot 3.0 comes out there's very little reason for me to stick with Unity3d, and I will heavily consider porting over to Godot.

33424024.review:
Okay I have put a semi-decent amount of hours into this thing. and Post quiet a bit on Github and itch.io, All my projects are free and open source. So take, and examine whatever you desire.
https://github.com/lavaduderDev
https://lavaduder.itch.io/

Lightweight, Free and OpenSource, Easy Node system, Great UI. 
Godot is made for people who: 

like building their games from stratch.
Enjoy a diverse script languages
Custumizing their game engines
Prefer linux over every other platform
Publish to html
low spec computers
Dive into other people's opensource projects and change them for the better.

Godot however is not for everyone, especially those that:

Prefer toying with assets (Unity is for you)
want to easily make games (Gamemaker, Construct2)
Use a lot of tools to make things shiny (Unreal)
Have a specific game genre in mind (various, like RPG maker) (However Godot does have Escoria Project, Which is for Point and Click Adventure games)
And have a huge library of tutorials to teach you (ANY OF THE ABOVE)

I've seen a lot of people suggest you wait for Godot 3.0. But I'd say learn it now. Once everything opens up to you, You'll never find a better engine. 

Godot's power is what you'd call a double-edged sword.
It's for those that at least have a half idea of what they are doing (Don't worry I am exception. Just look up the Q&A, Which is farely active.), beginners are welcomed to try, but it is not the easiest to learn. Gdscript is undoubtably easier than C++.

My favorite part of Godot is the Node system. Organized, and simple. I can call a node function, get a node variable, load a script in, instance a scene, or signal it on command. With very little hassle. The list of node types and their node family inheritants are quickly understood. 

Because Godot is FOSS it is customizable for everyone, If you prefer C# over the default gdscript, gdscript can be replaced, prefer to work on linux over windows? No problem. (infact it seems like that was the targeted audience.) And if you don't like where the engine is going, you can fork it. (Also if you do that, PLEASE CALL IT GODOT MATE!) It fits in with my other FOSS software, like musescore2, Lmms, Gimp, and Blender(Godot actually has plugins for Blender!)

The Escoria Project. To me this changes Godot completely. I'm still using that familar UI, but with very powerful point and click adventure tools, I especially love the dialog system. esc script can make really complexe dialog trees, and I love it! I've been wanting to make a point and click adventure ever since I started using game engines, and now I got the best one for the job. It's a dream come true!

But not all is good. My biggest complaint with Godot is the lack of tutorials, and those that exist need improving, But that's a community issue. Of a community driven engine.

It's also Still early in development. A lot of stuff is missing. Infact very recently enumerators were added to gdscript. STINKING ENUMS! Plus The lighting is awful, like other game engines, it does not spread out, annoying hot spots are frequent. It's a disaster when making dark areas.

overall I do recommend Godot, if it appeals to you. I came because of the node system, but stayed because I felt I can help shape a community, Thanks to Escoria and Dolphin Island 2.

I've been playing around with Godot for nearly a year and it's a fantastic piece of kit:

[list]
[*] Free and Open Source
[*] No royalties required
[*] Runs on Windows, Mac and Linux
[*] Cross platform and mobile export available from the get-go
[*] Built in tools for animation, shaders, particles, etc
[*] Easy to learn Python-like language
[*] Version 3.0 on the horizon
[/list]

It's not as well known as Unity and perhaps not quite as robust as Gamemaker, but both of those tools are either premium or require royalties. Version 3.0 is out soon with a revised UI and some great new features. If you're a pro or experienced developer, you may find Godot lacking in some areas, but if you're curious about making and programming games then definitely give it a shot.

32752522.review:
A flexible and customizable game editor that can be powerful in the right hands. 

There's a lot of capability and can make some visually stunning effects without being too taxing on the CPU/GPU. 

The node system paired with the screens system allows for ease of use and the scripting system paired with the signal system allows for a variety of possibility inside the game as well as in the code. 

At the moment, the language available is GDscript which works a lot like python, but in 3.0 they'll be unveiling C# as another possible language for even more accessable code. 

It allows you to be really creative, but it will take a while to learn. Luckily, there are enough video tutorials online where people that have played around and gotten more acquainted with the software that it's easy enough for a beginner to learn and play around with to get just as acquainted. 

As long as your mind is open, and you're willing to learn, you'll have a great time with this.

Edit: My hours are low since I use the version offline of steam, but I have played around with this software for about 24 hours.

5.官方一直在更新，但是好像没啥效率，建议观望以后看如何发展。
-------------------------------------------------
ps：别看官方做的游戏好像很不错！用这软件做那些效果很麻烦，你用其他引擎能少走很多弯路！
------------------------------------------------

体验了几个小时以下随便说几点。

-界面没有想象中的友好
但是这软件的没有引导部分，你还是去查看观看官方文档。（虽然简单，但是去和橙光比比就会明显感觉这个软件不够小白）
而且软件要求的脚本语言gdscript，虽然比c#容易套多，但是也没你们想的那么简单，看我看到不但没有简化，而且增加了开发成本。

-素材库不够强大
这软件没有绘制工具也就是说哪怕你只要绘制一个方块，也要从外部导入。
像把图片旋转也只能改数值。
虽然想RPG maker也没有图片绘制工具，但是RPG maker有强大的内置素材库，然而这软件没有。
虽然有Godot Asset Library但是也才7页，太少了。。

-gdscript没想象中的强大
gdscript语言局限性太强如果你只是开发一个简单的文字游戏，我觉得你没必要选这个软件。
但是有如果想做稍微好玩一点的3D游戏，你就知道很多东西，你还是得靠C++去写。

-做出的游戏没有想象中的效果
看官方提供的demo其实没有很多惊艳的效果，他能做的unity都能做。（而且unity实现起来还更简单，你在untiy的官方demo随便改就做出比这个软件效果好太多的东西）。
如果我只是为了做简单的游戏，我建议你选一个上手难度更低的引擎。想要效果好一点，你用这个软件开发真的效率很低。

-官方模板
官方模板我看了一个遍，有些效果确实很好玩。
但是真的能拿来做游戏吗？我觉得官方的模板更像是geek实验型的，都是些半成品。相比实用性就比不过其他引擎的了，别的模板你随便改改就是一个游戏，本以为gooogle开发的东西，会各种高端炫酷有，然而我看到的只是些半成品。

-软件轻便
我看到评论很多人说这软件轻便，但是如果你真的想做自己的游戏，我觉得你不会考虑轻便这个要素，除非你是在网吧做游戏，经常要换机子。
而且说轻便这软件只能说一般吧，不如rpgmaker这种轻便。

-感觉这软件官方没花啥精力做
这软件一启动啥都不干，都能弹出一堆ERROR信息，而且软件本身看起来就像一个未完成品。而且这么多年依然这样，我觉得官方没有本身就没花太多精力在这个上面。
当然和本身这是开源软件，开发商目前没盈利，所以没花什么资金去研发也有关。
最后现在跨平台什么的不能作为卖点了，现在是个引擎都可以跨平台。

30494132.review:
I have tried my best to review various game engines, and Unity is unrivaled in functionality, with deployment on many different platforms and development on both Win, Mac, and Linux (Linux client still beta, but fully functional). If I would pick anything else than Unity, I would pick CryEngine because of its beautiful 3D rendering, or Lumberyard for both CryEngine beauty and Amazon Web Services. 

Godot looks great if you didn't look at Unity or any other options. But after looking into the different engines that are available at this time (2017), Godot is just left far behind on so many things. The only thing that Godot has going for it is the MIT license which makes it completely free, compared to for example Unity where you need to pay some licensing if you start making more than 100'000 USD per year, at which point you really should reward the game engine developers anyway, unless you are a total douchebag. 

Speaking of douchebags, it is my impression that the Godot community is rather hostile and not really nice people. Maybe I was just unlucky in my interactions. Without naming any names, just look at this Steam review, which previously pointed out a bug that made Godot entirely unusable. One of the comments said that "this negative review doesn't count because bugs are not part of a programs functionality" [slightly edited]. So apparently, having a bug that renders a software impossible to use is not part of that softwares functionality?!? Anyway, I mentioned this bug in my first review, which made one of the developers respond and work to fix it, so great job on his part. However, while I reported a bug that made the software impossible to use and while that report resulted in a developer responding and fixing said bug, 83% of the Godot users came in to say that my review was "not helpful". 

So according to the Godot user community, bugs that render a software useless should not be part of a review because it has nothing to do with functionality, and reporting those bugs so that they can be fixed is "not helpful". This is just one example of my interactions with Godot users, but I really don't have any kind of positive impression of the community. Meanwhile, other engines have users that produce tutorials and act generally friendly with advice and help. Again, this may be some unfortunate and unlucky things that only applied to me, but it is my own experiences and impressions. You might be more lucky, if you want to risk it. 

To sum up, I don't think Godot is bad software. It's just not even close to other software, and the user community appears to be less friendly and helpful than what I have found elsewhere. Therefore, I would recommend anyone to try out Unity, Lumberyard/CryEngine, Unreal Engine, and the other options out there that are most likely better than Godot in every possible aspect.

30023095.review:
Working with this engine has been an absolute pleasure. Steam has only recorded a fraction of the time I have spent with the engine - I've easily sunk a couple hundred hours into this engine.

Pros:
**Clean interface, that's easy on the eyes.
**Built-in Code editor/Compiler that's easy to work with.
**Great Engine developers that actively listen and work to keep the engine moving forward with bug patches, feature updates and promotions.
**Don't need to pay any royalties if you release your game commercially.
**Huge library of "nodes" (elements of your game) that make development much easier.
**Very powerful 2D engine that is capable of creating any 2D game you can think up.
**Open-Source Engine
**Multi-platform support (PC, Mac, Linux, Console, Blackberry ect)

Cons:
==You have to learn GDScript (which is very similar to python)
==The 3D engine is a bit lacking in some areas. (still very capable for most indie projects and there are often workarounds)

Notes:
As of this post the engine developers are actively working on a new 3D component. From what I have read so far, the new 3D component will feature a more modern OpenGL renderer with Physically based shading. This is excellent news in my opinion that's worth mentioning - because it shows that the guys behind godot are pushing the engine where the community wants it to go.

Overall, an excellent engine I'd easily recommend.

29996200.review:
This review was *almost* a positive recommendation.  You can read a lot of the other positive reviews to learn why it's a really good development framework.

I was about to choose Godot as the engine for my next game, but then my partner noticed that there were posts dating from over a year ago reporting screen tearing and frame stuttering, and these reports continued up to the present.  (Search for "godot screen tearing" to see some of the posts.)

I had not noticed the problem because the scenes we had made for our evaluation project did not have scrolling.  As soon as I added some scrolling to the project, I saw the problems.  Unfortunately, there seems to be no workaround.  Even Godot's own Space Shooter demo has the problems.  Neither turning VSync on (or off) nor enabling pixel snapping helped.  It would sometimes look so bad that one could clearly see the seam flicker between two triangles of a texture.

Once Godot fixes the screen tearing and frame stuttering, I will gladly change my recommendation to "Yes", but for now, it's not good for commercial use.  It's still good for personal projects, prototyping, and game jams.

UPDATE (25 Feb): As another test, I created a project with no scrolling.  It was simply a 4-color Sprite node that one could drag around the screen, and the background was a solid color.  If I dragged the sprite rapidly around the top 1/3 of the screen, I would see weird ripples inside the sprite. Slower movement minimized the rippling, but it was still noticeable.  I don't think it's simply a hardware issue because similar behavior does not happen if I recreate the demo in GameMaker, Corona, or Unity.  It seems like a renderer issue to me.  I hope Godot 3's new renderer fixes the problem!

29752948.review:
First of all I've used Godot much more than 22 hours, just not the Steam version.

Started out disliking Godot because of GDScript but after some weeks with it, the scripting language stopped being an issue.
Other than that, I'd say this engine is well on its way to become a premier RAD (does anyone even use this term anymore ? :D) environment for making games.

Battle-tested in 2 game jams and one LD.

PROS:
[list]
[*]Good level editor, comes with multiple camera manipulation modes (including my favourite, Maya).
[*]Great for 2D games (just as good as other, more expensive, engines)
[*]GDScript offers a tighter integration with the engine than most other scripting engines.
[*]Offers a decent debugger.
[*]Complex properties (matrices, colors) are edited in pop-up boxes and don't clutter the GUI.
[*]Lots of pre-existing components to help with collision, navigation, 2D and 3D tiled levels and more.
[*]Many demos and open source examples that cover a wide range of topics.
[/list]

CONS:
[list]
[*]Complex projects will sometimes crash the editor if you work too fast (e.g. when switching between 2D, 3D and Script editors).
[*]Importing 3D animated models could go smoother.
Because licensing issues prevent Godot from supporting FBX (the industry standard right now), you [b]WILL have to use 3rd party software[/b] to convert assets to COLLADA (.DAE) (Blender, Maya, MAX, etc).
[*]Have to learn a new language (GDScript) but it's syntax is similar to Python.
[/list]

I've used a lot of game engines in my time. Unreal, Unity, Game Editor, Love2d and out of all of them Godot has become my favorite engine. Considering how simple it is, it's wildly powerful. Once you learn how to use it you feel like you're using a well tuned instrument. I find myself working on features I've never made before and just *knowing* what I need to do to make them.

29438651.review:
요약: 인디용으로는 차고 넘치는 훌륭한 무료 도구이나 상업용으로는 글쎄.

[h1]개요[/h1]

괜찮긴 한데 적응하는데 좀 걸릴겁니다. 이런 툴들은 보통 무료*라는 게 가장 크게 먹혀들어가는 점이죠.

유니티는 안 써봐서 모르겠는데 씬 구성하는 컨셉자체가 새롭다보니 이거 적응하는데도 좀 걸립니다.

파이썬과 유사하지만 더 경량인 GDScript라는 자체 언어를 사용합니다. 개발중인 3.0 (2018.01 기준 알파) 에서는 비주얼 스크립팅과 C#을 지원합니다. 클래스의 문서화는 그럭저럭 잘 되어있는 편입니다.

2.x 시점에서는 3D 기능이 모자라다는 중론이 있습니다**. 2D는 (안 써봤지만) spine 같은 애니메이팅을 자체지원***하는 등 괜찮은 모습을 보여줍니다. UI 구성도 체계적으로 할 수 있습니다****.

아, 근데 주변에서 이거 영업하면 약 파는 거니까 취미로 배우는 거 아니면 유니티 하러 가세요. 물론 저는 약을 팔 겁니다.

----
* 오픈소스(MIT 라이센스, 즉 엔진을 수정해도 공개하지 않아도 됨)
** 따라서 3.0은 3D에 치중하는 것 같습니다.
*** 에디터에 애니메이션 편집기 존재
**** 관련 클래스/노드 다수 지원
----

[h1]일장일단[/h1]

- 장점: 오픈소스(MIT), 무료
- 단점: 코드에 주석 좀 다세요 제발 코드가 스스로 말하는 것도 정도가 있지

- 장점: 파이썬 같은 배우기 쉬운 자체 언어. 덕타이핑 가능
- 단점: 파이썬이 아니라 원하는 문법이 없을 때가 종종 있음. 아직 람다 안 됨
- 해소: 3.0 에서 C#, 비주얼 스크립팅 지원. 여러 다른 언어도 사용 가능. 엔진 재컴파일 할 필요 없음.

- 장점: 트리 형식의 씬 구성으로 트리의 일부를 저장하고 재활용
- 단점: 트리 형식으로 구성하는 방법에 적응하는 데 좀 걸림

- 장점: 내장 애니메이션 툴, 모든 속성을 애니메이팅할 수 있음
- 단점: 뭔가 툴이 애매한 감이
- 해소: 3.1? 에서 보강된다고 함

- 장점: 강력한 UI 지원 - 다양한 클래스 및 컨테이너, 스킨도 지원
- 애매: XML은 아니고 트리 기반임, 에디터 사용, 별도 창 띄우는 게 아직 불가능

- 장점: 2D와 3D를 별도로 분리해서 지원함. 이 면에선 애매한 유니티같은 거보다 나음
- 단점: 3D가 구리다는 평이 많음
- 해소: 3.0 에서 3D를 여러모로 보강한다던데 전문분야가 아니라 잘;

- 장점: 멀티플랫폼 이식 가능. 해당 플랫폼용 엔진 실행파일과 게임 데이터만 있으면 됨
- 단점: 안드 광고 붙이기 힘들다던데 안 해봐서 모르겠음. 메뉴얼에 방법이 있긴 함

- 장점: 에디터가 멀티플랫폼. 심지어 하이쿠OS도 지원
- 애매: 애매하게 지원해서 힘들 때도 있는데 이건 버그사냥을 해야할 부분이죠

댓글로 질문 받습니다.

[h1]관련 정보[/h1]

튜토리얼 시리즈는 보통 GDquest 씨의 유튜브 강좌를 추천하고요, 메뉴얼도 잘 되어있는 편이라 영문이라서 좀 버겁더라도 메뉴얼을 따라 읽어봐도 좋습니다. 한글 문서는 누가 번역해둔 것들이 좀 있는 것 같더군요.

I'ts a bit interesting coming from unity 3D into Godot. However programming wise, you're going to have to get use to the python style of no curly braces with the Godot's own custom scripting language. Other than that as a major difference it is quite similar to unity 3D.

the software has a MIT license meaning:
 - you don't have to share the source code
 - you can use for commercial purposes
 - any game you make is completly yours
 - no paying ANY fees for using the engine

the game engine is still in it's early stages so you don't have all the nice polish and ultra awesome stuff that engines like UE4 have. But the best part about Godot is that it is free, they give you the source code and pretty musch just let you run with it.

Downsides:
 currently there is an issue where you cannot chane the logo/icon for the exported executable (i'm using windows version), however I'm confident that it will get fixed in the future (eventually). note- if there is a way to fix it via creating a build from source i'll probably do a tutorial on it.

another downside is the limited import options for 3d models. Godot (at the time of writing ver 2.1) only accepts .DAE for importing rigged models with animations. thankfully though on the Godot website they have a blender plugin : https://godotengine.org/download

Personally it takes some getting used to, but with all the lack of restrictions with licencing and fees its not a bad engine at all.

    [*] Completely free without hidden cost or royalty
[/list]

[h1] Cons	[/h1]
[list]
    [*] Annoying programming syntax
    [*] Demo project included inside the game engine didn't have detailed explanation
    [*] Limited resources (no UE4's Marketplace or Unity5's Asset Store equivalent to buy asset for your project)
[/list]

[h1] Comparison with UE4	[/h1]

GGE have better, clear and easy to understand documentation especially for tutorial section compared to UE4 documentation. Especially for a newcomer, this will help them to learn and grasp the basic in programming, mechanic and developing their own game. Plus with GGE own interface, it won't make the newcomer feel overwhelmed like UE4 own interface.

Personal opinion, if you're aspiring dev who have a "big idea" to be realized then you better go for UE4 (or Unity5). Especially where UE4 itself is designated for epic 3D AAA game or simple 2D Flappy Bird-esque game, everythings is possible. With vast arsenal of useful tools like visual programming-esque language, profiler, real-time debug and WYSIWYG, it definitely will speed up and make your game development much easier. 

Although the learning curve for UE4 is quite steep, in a long term investment it defenitely worth your time. Plus it's free (excluding 5% royalty on that amount after the first $3000 per game per calendar quarter).

[h1] Comparison with Unity5	[/h1]

Another game engine that sell like hotcakes among indie game dev or hobbyist. 

Have been using UE4 for almost 1 year and GGE for 1 week before my friend ask me to help him create 360° video VR inside Unity5. Can't say much about the pros and cons but one thing for sure, Unity5 is easier than GGE and probably almost equivalently feature-wise like UE4. 

The huge con for someone who reconsidering to get Unity5 instead GGE is the Unity5 license for Plus and Pro are quite expensive (with 12 month of continuous subscription commitment).

[h1] Conclusion	[/h1]

If you are the one who need a free, not license restricted (like Unity5) and looking for easy, not so hard game engine (like UE4), you should try GGE. If you like the game engine you should consider to make some donation to ensure that the developer can add more feature to this awesome software.

TL;DR: GET IT! Amazing piece of open source software with great development and community. Increasing in power and functionality with every release. Free as in free-beer!

(My hours with it here on Steam don't reflect my hours with the standalone install.)

--------

I recently got back into game development after a very long time and have been reviewing various engines and creation tools including Unity, UE, Gamemaker, Clickteam, RPG Maker, Adventure Game Studio and others.

I stumbled on Godot tutorials on Youtube and checked it out after seeing the Brave Bran demos. After some initial testing, I gotta say there's just something about its presentation and streamlined simplicity that make me keep coming back. The UI looks almost sparse at first but I find that actually keeps me more focused because the layout is tidy.  

That doesn't mean it's lacking in functionality at all though. The visual node-based/blueprint shader engine is a godsend for those who want to try GLSL shaders but aren't so great with the code side. This same system is also being developed for the engine scripting as well and that can be a HUGE feature for many. Check out the videos on YouTube regarding this feature.

There's just too many nice features to mention really but it all just seems to *work* well from the flow of the development to the samples and demos included.

Users are also contributing plugins such as an amazing bone-based 2D IK system similar to Spline/Spriter for Blender that exports to Godot. Asset dropper/management plugins and other goodies are also available.

There are no license fees involved with Godot itself when exporting your work so that's a bonus as many engines have royalty clauses for commercial games.

I'm really impressed with this engine and hope the development and community continue to grow and contribute to an even more robust product.

10/10

25076549.review:
This game engine is so great, I can't say enough good things. One thing to note is even though this engine in fairly fresh to the public, it had been used exclusively in-house by OKAM studios for about a decade while simultaneously adding new features to the engine to fit their needs in it's closed source past.

That the engine has such beginnings is very reassuring. It had to meet the needs of developers in-person and get games out the door. That it is now being refined as an open-source engine makes it even better. Developers around the world alongside the responsive lead developers are intelligently managing this project with lots of fantastic updates and it has turned into my absolute favorite engine ever because of their efforts.

Let's break it down with a classic pros & cons list.

---

Pros:

Absolutely free & open source. Unlike other big name engines, you won't be charged no matter how much you profit from the result. You can mess with the base code all you want and compile the result for your own team.

Binaries for Linux are provided regularly, including here on Steam!

A familiar UI to other modern engines with no shortage of good inspiration & careful design.

Includes a pythonic scripting language named GDscript that is suited for the engine.

The node system is packed with lots of great base objects.

A powerful animator that can change any variable exposed to the engine over time!

Outside of games it has plenty of tools to make traditional applications too.

Contains plugin API so you can expand on the engine even from GDscript itself. 

Has an asset store so you can share those plugins, perhaps some assets or even game templates.

Dark theme by default!

Great for low-res/retro style & needs few tweaks unlike other big name engines.

Great controller support, I've been able to get both X Input & Direct Input to work with zero issues.

Can be ported to pretty much everything since it has a C++ base. Windows, Linux, Android, OSX, iOS & HTML5 are all available. OKAM have released their games for various console platforms, so that is very possible to do as well.

The visual scripting system is soon coming in 2.2 and looks promising.

C# support is in the works.


Cons:

It still uses GLES2 for the rendering API, which means more advanced graphical effects will not be available & in the worse case you may suffer from a stuttering effect that may be tied to this being the only option. There are plans to add GLES3 support soon as well as Vulkan down the road to correct this.

The documentation is a bit weak, but it's gotten much better over the past half year.

---

In conclusion, just get it! You've got nothing to lose, it's absolutely free and I think many of you will find it easy to love. Video tutorials are a bit lacking out there so I'm considering sharing what I know with some videos myself. Check me out on Youtube with the same name if you're interested as I'll have some stuff up in the near future. If you are licensed for a console platform and are porting your game to one, I would love to hear your results.

I'll try to update this now & again as the engine is actively evolving.

The major "con" out of the way this engine is quite powerful and easy to use.

To do anything substantial YOU do need to know how to code (in general terms - all languages have nuances but the same generalized constructs for logic, loops, and abstractions are the same)

The 3D component part of this is targeted primarily for mobile platforms where an engine like Leadwerks, for example, is geared for higher end PC.  The 2D aspect of this software is quite powerful.

If you wish to get into game development this is free, no strings, and quite capable.  If you are a veteran in the industry you can do some things with this as well but it does currently target lower end hardware devices; then again if you are in the industry you already heard of this engine and will not be reading reviews but sampling it yourself to see if it suits your needs.

It's free software regardless.  If you happen to read this review and you want to make a game this is a good place to start at the high end of beginning and intermediate level with no cost to you.   Until you can justify paying for an engine don't kid yourself trying to use the other AAA engines until you learn how to code.  You will never get away from being required to write code to make anything substantial that stands out.  Period.

22445121.review:
Godot, the underdog of the open scene of Game Engines Battle Royale. It's one of the least known game engines out there, which I myself discovered just mere month ago. Boy was I surprised to see something like this on the "market". It's an opensource 2D and 3D game engine, with a main focus on 2D (as of now, in version 2.0.2; 3D improvements and quite a lot more stuff! is coming in version 3) but which can also do 3D, though not as intuitive. But the best part of it all is the great community, responsive devs. (just try it out in their IRC chat: freenode - #godotengine & #godotengine-devel, like right now!) and best of all it's MIT license which basically means you can do whatever the hell you want with it. It is also poewrful enought to get you started in games ranging from simple to advanced. The editor itself is built in Godot! yah, you heard right, the editor is actually a game, how cool is that? Anyway, on to the more serious part (I'll focus more on 2D cause that's what I've been experimenting with):

Pros:
[list]
  [*]it has all the tools you need to fast prototype your game, though crude, they're super useful. Don't have artistic abilities? Just try  out the polygon tool for building graphics quickly, run the game without compiling it, for debugging purposes. It has real time updates, that is if you run your game and change it while it's running, the changes will reflect in the game play! Super useful
  [*]the way they put it together really follows the simplicity philosophy: the tools are all nodes in a tree which means you can easily prototype and implement complex scenes (which are themselves nodes, which is why I actually don't like referring to them as scenes, they're basically just nodes, everything is a node in Godot, it's really important to get this mindset when starting out, it will definitely help in the long run, trust me!) in a very straightforward way. Games usually have a hierarchy structure to them which can be thought from the beginning: the player is a character, the character has weapons, armor, stats, the wold comprises of the map and the characters, the map contains props etc. All this shows how easy it is to build a graph or a tree of the game which can literally be replicated in Godot. There's no need for Prefabs or other workarounds that you might find in Unity or other game engines. Here in Godot everything fits in quite naturally
  [*]the GDScript Godot uses for the logic of interactive nodes is very simple and fast to learn. It's based on Python (I'd say 80% or more is overlap) which goes back to the fast prototyping paradigm. It's essential to have a simple scripting language to bring life to your characters and artwork. It's also enough powerful and straightforward to use for simple to complex objects.
  [*]build custom nodes through GDSCript which you can then use in the editor! Missing a node? Just build one yourself, it's really easy once you get the hang of GDScript
  [*]if there's functionality missing in the engine (which requires specific access to hardware or needs to run buttery smooth) just write a C/C++ module or Java if you are developing for Android, etc. which means you're not limited to work only with what's been given.
  [*]it's MIT licensed, this is huge! Use it, modify it, distribute it, do whatever you want with it and it's all free! no hidden costs or fees, no nothing, just take it, use it, build something marvelous!
  [*]animation is built wright inside of it! with armature and what not, just try it
  [*]build for any platform, ranging from Windows, Linux to hand-held devices, consoles etc. you name it
  [*]more and more people are taking interest in it. For example take a look at this brand new tool for blender: https://github.com/ndee85/coa_tools
  [*]of course, last but not least, it's opensource which mean anyone can contribute!
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
  [*]documentation is scarce, but it will eventually improve, there's a lot of refactoring going on as we speak and it's constantly updated
  [*]]if there's functionality missing in the engine (which requires specific access to hardware or needs to run buttery smooth) just write a C/C++ module or Java if you are developing for Android, etc. which means you're not limited to work only with what's been given. You might remember this from the "Pros" list. I've also included it in the "Cons" because it's not easy to get things rolling if you don't have experience with lower level languages or with specific platform languages. I sure am no expert in Java for example which means I won't be able to take full advantage of the hand-held hardware, unless I dig in and learn some Java to build my own modules, or rely on someone else to come up with the functionality, it's both a Pro and a Con
  [*]relying on it's own GDScript means yet another language to master and you may find it just isn't powerful enough for your needs. Now the engine itself was built with multiple scripting languages in mind so at some point we might find that it will support Javascript or Python or what not, but for now we're stuck with GDScript
  [*]it's still early in development which means some features are missing or there's bugs, but hey... show me a commercial product out there which doesn't include bugs!
[/list]

Can't wait for Godot 3 which will a complete revamp of the particle system, it will be focused on 3D functionality and it will move on to the new Vulkan graphics API which is quite ambitious. So far the devs are on top of it and they have delivered every time! I guess it help that they are actually payed to work on this project, even though it's open source :). All considered I think this is one of the best game engines out there and on top of it it's open source! Definitely recommended!

Godot en un motor de juegos de pequeño tamaño pero grande en posibilidades, en el cual se pueden realizar juegos tanto en 2D como 3D, disponible en diferentes plataformas como los son Windows, Linux y OS X, y en el que pueden luego exportar tus juegos resultantes a las plataformas antes mencionadas sumando Android, iOS, Blackberry OS y de forma experimental HTML5.

En el departamento 2D es uno de los motores para juegos más completo que existe (incluso superando algunos de pago), y siendo gratis, de código abierto, sin requerir de regalías, y con total libertad para hacer con el producto lo que desees, no hay mejor trato que este motor a la hora de hacer juegos en 2D; en el departamento 3D está aun un poco verde y carece de las opciones avanzadas y posibilidades que tienen los otros motores comerciales, sin embargo se pueden hacer buenos juegos y visualmente atractivos en 3D.

El interfaz es limpio y el lenguaje "GDScript" es de fácil aprendizaje, y al estar basado en Python si ya conoces este lenguaje, el aprendizaje será aun más fácil; habiendo dicho esto, ya he dado a entender que deberán poner código por ustedes mismos, aunque esto no es gran problema ya que hay ejemplos y tutoriales de los que pueden tomar "prestado" código.

Me gustaría que Godot estubiera en español, espero que lo traduscan en un futuro cercano.

22418430.review:
First things first:
Although in steam I have just less than an hour of use time with it, I have been using Godot for months now and also tried my hand at Unity and some other less-known engines.
My background until Godot was basically using softwares from Click Team and also Scirra's Construct 2.


It is a fantastic engine, created from the ground up to be really modular. The nodes concept, something that just came to unity is a very handy and a really nice feature.
It also has so many features, it exports to pc, mac, linux, android, IOS and HTML5, although the HTML5 exporter has some catch-up to do compared to the other exporters. 

You can create games as simple and as complex as you want, Godot uses a language that is basically python rebranded so, it is pretty easy to pick it up and make things...

The editor itself is packed with features to make awesome 2D and 3D games and the animation system deserves an entire review by itself. You can animate everything. Create cutout-style animation, animate opacity, position, any kind of value. In no time you'll have your character coming to life.

It is free and open source software, so you have complete control of your game, your code is yours only.

Have a look at the first game I made and also take a look at the game jam that happened during March of 2016, you'll be happily surprised with this engine.
Link: https://gamedl8.itch.io/mice-a-ball

There is also a lot of resources to learn godot over at youtube and its documentation and tutorials is also growing on a day-by-day basis.

If you have used construct2 or multimedia fusion and feel you could benefit from having more control over things, go to Godot, that's at least the main cause I jumped from Construct2 to it. The learning curve won't be as hard as you think.

If you have experience with any other engine, like unity, coco2D, unreal, etc... you'll learn godot in no time and will acknowledge how thight, completel and unbloated this engine is.

22073893.review:
I want to tell everyone how terrible this game engine is so I can keep it all to myself.
Like all game engines, there's a bit of learnig curve involved, but there are some great tutorial series on YouTube to take care of that.
PROS
-------
This thing just ticks all the boxes for me:
* There is no license fee to use this - ever.
* Very powerful engine and powerful features.
* Terriffic set of examples (both quantity and quality) come bundled allowing you to see how things are coded.
* It's open source.
* It uses (nearly) python for the scripting language, making it very. very easy to write code for.
* Great editor with code completion
* Has a dedicated 2D physics engine AND a dedicated 3D physics engine.
* Exports to about every platfor you can think of (iOS, android, linux, mac, and that Redmond stuff ;)
* Rapid developement
* An innovative and VERY useful inheritance structure
* Pluggins for Blender - model in blender, import to Godot
* Even isometric games are possible
* You wouldn't believe the number of built in object types (called "nodes") that can do things for you
* Good community
* Actively being developed
* Live Editing - you can apparently deploy to a tablet and change the level on the fly from your rig

CONS:
---------
* No one's ever heard of this thing
* Documentation is a little lite. It's there, but it's for the prior version, though most of it is still applicable
* Documentation needs more examples and use cases
* No documentation on how to set up the Live Editing
* The community, though friendly, feels like it's small - because no one's ever heard of this great product

Conclusion
-------------
Say goodbye to Unity3D, Constuct, and Stencyl - this thing is amazing. Every engine has a learning curve, once you get past that, this thing is very powerful and a joy to use.

Update:
-----------
As of the new version 2.0.1, all the documentation is now up to date and built right into the editor. You just put your cursor on a word and press SHIFT-F1 and go right to the relevant doc page.

21864998.review:
ABSOLUTELY THE BEST 2D GAME ENGINE IN THE WORLD, EVER. PERIOD. (If you're a serious dev and not a wannabe.) IT PUTS EVERY OTHER 2D GAME ENGINE TO ABSOLUTE SHAME.

Ignore my number of hours on this engine. I've spent way more hours with the builds I compiled myself before it even got on to Steam. Even now, I always compile my own Godot for the latest and greatest, and I still can't keep up. They develop so often and so rapidly that they push out commits with new features and bugfixes so frequent, I gave up trying to pull and compile the sources just to have the latest. Nowadays I only do it when I feel like it. 

For 2D development, Godot is a FULL-FLEDGE game engine which surpasses everything by a far stretch. It is tons better than Unity, Unreal Engine, GameMaker: Studio, Clickteam Fusion 2.5 etc, and Construct 2 when the Visual Scripting is ready (except for maybe, everything about asset stores, and bigger communities, etc). 

It doesn't fake its rendering of 2D by using a 3D camera minus the axis of depth (like Unity does). Looking at its source code, even if you may not agree with it, you probably can't help but wonder what an engineering wonder this is! Imagine how perfect this engine could be (or already is for many gamedevs), as Godot is only limited by one thing: the people in the community using it to make games and contributing to develop it further, available plugins for 3rd-party IDEs.

Makes anyone wonder why Godot isn't THE mainstream game engine for 2D yet. I prototype 2D games a lot so I've used plenty of game engines (absurd to list them here) and Godot is by far the greatest 2D all-in-one integrated game engine in the world surpassing everything out there except custom in-house engines that are not available for public use. It's hard to believe, but I'm not exaggerating at all. 

Keep in mind that this is AN ACTUAL GAME ENGINE / FRAMEWORK, not some no-coding drag-and-drop visual programming wannabe bullshit, even though it has visual scripting in the works.

So you're gonna need to code a lot, and a lot I mean A FUCKING LOT. And I said FRAMEWORK too since you can actually completely ignore the whole visual side of Godot and use it like MonoGame, libGDX, etc, coding purely in C++ (git clone https://github.com/godotengine/godot.git) if you're like an oh-so-hardcore-esque low-level wiz from the 70s.

Take note that I am a VERY BIG FAN of Unity and everything Unity. I've also used GameMaker: Studio and Clickteam's various products in the past.

Yet, I still use this as my main engine over any other option available out there because:

- Full source code access. MIT license. Freedom.

- Extremely active developers. Just look at their GitHub repos. Just look.

- Very easy compilation for Windows, Mac, Linux, Android, iOS, HTML5 etc.

- C++ source/framework. Devs seem to use QtCreator as their IDE. Easy low-level gamedev. C98 datatypes.

- You can write your own modules, easily, provided you are familiar with programming in C++/Java.

- C++ modules. Very modular. Even GDScript is a module. Have to recompile to enable modules.

- GDScript plugin system. No need to recompile.

- Tool mode (Godot's editor scripting if you come from Unity).

- True cross-platform with mutliplatform editor: Windows, Mac, Linux, etc!

- I prefer instancing scenes of nodes within other scenes of nodes over components on GameObjects in big scenes.

- Tiny, efficient executable.

- Visual shader editor. No need to buy something like ShaderForge (Unity). Shader language too.

- Animate anything animation system a la Unity's Mechanim.

- Bones for 2D skeletal animation with IK. No need to buy Spriter Pro or Spine! I just wish we can export the animation to image files.

- IAP system (enable its singleton to enable the module).

- Want to let an object be tappable on a mobile screen or clickable on the desktop? Easy, just check one option: "Pickable". Done.

- True 2D.

- Very very very easy pause system. 

- Has something like AssetBundle (if you come from Unity).

- Crazy signals system and GUI nodes and CanvasLayer make GUI building easy even for kindergarten kids.

- Theming GUI with your own skins? As if this world has anything easier in any other software out there.

- Can be used to make DESKTOP software. (Don't try to make mobile apps yet though since it doesn't do low-power mode on mobile yet)

- Your own splashscreen.

- THEMABLE DARK THEME!

- https://www.facebook.com/groups/godotengine/ THE COMMUNITY IS HYPERACTIVE ON FACEBOOK!!!

- MANY MORE!



Cons are:

- WORST IF YOU CAN'T CODE.

- If you don't like GDScript because it's like Python. Or because it's "not a real language" 

JUSTIFICATION: But it's so easy to pick up, I didn't even read the docs before I guessed my way around the API and got the hang of it in just a couple of hours.

- HTML5 export is flawed. 

JUSTIFICATION: But they're working on it. They just got a lump sum of $$$ from Mozilla. I'm Waiting for Godot 3.0+.

- Relatively tinier community.

JUSTIFICATION: But very very active, especially their Facebook group. ESPECIALLY THEIR FACEBOOK GROUP. It's even more active than your emo friends' tantrum-throwing posts every few minutes.

- Has an "Asset Store". Little content. NO VR export.

JUSTIFICATION: Give it time. It's still new so it's GROWING. 

- Godot structuring a game as one big tree with many branching nodes may not sit well with some people coming from other engines and frameworks at first sight.

JUSTIFICATION:  But if you actually stop being prejudicial and spend some time to learn and change your thinking a bit, it is the BEST out there and if you're a developer who has experience shipping games, your productivity will increase by 99999999%.

- Maybe you think you can't export to consoles? 

JUSTIFICATION: YOU CAN! It's not stated anywhere on the website and due to legal reasons you have to contact and prove to a Godot core developer/maintainer you're a licensed developer for a particular console first before they send you the export templates.

- Plenty of info in the docs but still not enough for many people?

JUSTIFICATION: It's GROWING. Give it time to grow.

- Not enough tutorials because not enough people using it. 

JUSTIFICATION: But this (http://www.gamefromscratch.com/page/Godot-Game-Engine-tutorial-series.aspx) will probably get you started VERY QUICKLY.

- There might be bugs here and there, just like every other engine.

JUSTIFICATION: But if you report it, it gets fixed in a few hours to at most a few days, if it's not a major bug. If it's a major bug, they're already working on the fix. Or it's already fixed.

- Certain links to certain Godot resources (like 3rd-party modules etc) from Google search results may be outdated and current ones may become obsolete very quickly because of the rate at which Godot is being developed.

JUSTIFICATION: The current number of game developers using Godot just isn't enough to keep up with the extremely rapid updates. If there are more people using Godot and contributing to it, this would be less of an issue (and I get to be lazy).



Also, take note that I don't really do 3D that much since doing 3D is too hard for my little brain.

I don't believe in things being absolute, but Godot is an exception. It is ABSOLUTELY THE BEST.

Provided you're not doing 3D. Haven't heard of any shipped games made with Godot? Only reason why it's not THE 2D GAME ENGINE? Because you haven't used it yet. Why don't you be the first to make a hit with it? Why don't you help push this engine to be THE ABSOLUTE GAME ENGINE?

Embrace Godot. Sniff it like weed. Or even better, make it a part of your physical body. Trust me, you will be a lot healthier than you are. You will be among the healthiest and fittest in the world. Truly the best. Repeat after me: "I am Godot. I am Godot. I am Godot.". Be one with it. Be Godot.

Then comes Godot, still Beta, but very much more refined, very active development too, I monitor commits to the source code. I submitted a bug report/suggestion two weeks ago, it just got fixed and pushed out in the nightly build. Nice!
If you can't make a game with this engine, then maybe game developing is not for you, but you do have to put in some work, learning GDscript (which is basically Python) is the only hard bit.

21651759.review:
I was looking for an open source game engine that would support all platforms including phones and web, when I stumbled upon Godot.  I have briefly played with other free engines, but this is the first one I've really commited to.  Been using it since the beginning of 2015. Here's what I like so far.

[list]
 [*] Scenes - You (can) break up your project into pieces, but still graphically manage everything from the interface.
 [*] Phone Apps - You can also create GUIs in godot.  Why not write a graphical phone app with a game engine?!
 [*] GDScript - At first I was bothered by it not supporting my language of choice, but since GDScript essentially a custom python based language.. I can easily port all kinds of python code to godot.  It's easy to pickup and hasn't held me back at all.
 [*] Documentation - With a project as complex as a game, I'm constantly solving problems I've never had to solve before.  The built in documentation in combination with the wiki usually have exactly what I'm looking for.  It's not perfect, and for more obscure things I'm sometimes digging a bit, but the docs keep improving and will only get better.
 [*]  Open Source - If it doesn't do some crazy feature I need for a project, I can add it.  I have had no need to do this, but I felt this was a big plus.  Kind of like having an in house engine you've developed.  If you really don't like how a feature works or one is missing.. You can fix that (and give back to the community)!
 [*] Rapid Development - I feel like one of the keys to figuring out what works and what doesn't is being able to try things quickly.  I can usually have something working within a few hours to test out whatever new concept i'm working on.
 [*] Built in Debugging - Output, performance metrics as well as deploying to a device.  Really handy stuff.
[/list]

 I'd say the downside would be it's still new, so it doesn't do EVERYTHING for you.  The new version supports community plugins and community assets are coming soon, so this should improve.  An example of this would be something like a dialog system.  You are left to create it however you like, but by no means is it drop in place and go.  I like that flexibility, as it allows me to have full control over everything.. not fighting an imposed system... but there's more learning curve there.

Overall, it has helped me quickly build some really cool stuff.  I often find myself enjoying the accomplishment of solving a problem for a silly little project I'm working much more than playing through a big budget game.  Give it a go!

21441899.review:
Been using Godot since early alpha. It's just come out on Steam.

It's not the kind of engine I can write a lot about. Not out of a lack of complexity, but out of admiration for the way it builds up on concepts others have thought of and addresses it's issues from the perspective of "how can our users achieve their goals better" as opposed to "how can we make an engine that is better than the other engines"?
That definement makes a world of difference.

Godot is an engine where you are a part of it. You don't download it and severe yourself from the development, hiding away with your application on your own. You contribute, you build it and you shape the future Godot holds. No matter what your goals are, there's a place available for you in this completely open source experience.

As for its functionality, the only limitation I have experienced is its struggle to make visually stunning 3D environments at a high level. Unless you're experienced with C++ I would suggest using Godot for 2D and non-graphically intensive applications. There's always room to learn.

In Godot, the main difference is the fact that all objects are "scenes", otherwise known as "nodes"; where everything is able to be called upon and referenced from anywhere in the engine. This makes it entirely fluent in any kind of global operations and instancing is extremely easy.

Updates are always happening. Tutorials are constantly being made. Do yourself a favour, and check Godot out.

21435444.review:
Some days I wake up screaming wishing we went Godot.

Doesn't try to re-invent how you traditionally structure a game like Unity 3D forces on you... nobody wants another engine where there is an entirely new vocabulary for the same shit we've seen a hundred times. Godot's editor acts as more of a "scene/object" editor rather than something that entirely forces the structure of your code.

One of the most amazing concepts of Godot is everything is either a "Scene" or a "Node"... instead of in Unity you have: Scenes, Prefabs, MonoBehaviours, GameObjects, Components, etc. in a very contrived version of C# "faked OOP" based on horribly slow language Reflection.

Reading the wiki tutorial from top to bottom will get you up to speed: http://docs.godotengine.org/

Pros of Godot
* Open source gem. Top notch support on all OS's including first class Linux.
* Very active development, stable.
* Python dialect is a pleasure to work in.
* Collaboration way above Unity: Godots "Scene" format is easy to merge and work with a full team.
* Building from source (only if you need to!) is straightforward and fast... I've tried it: it works well!
* Signal to noise ratio: Unity really suffers from of "95% of my users are the greenest of green".

Cons of Godot vs Unity
* VR support is not good yet.
* Slightly slower physics engine than Unity.
* Not as many 3rd party plugins or "tutorials" as Unity (not a huge problem if you know what you are doing).
* No C# option. But if you love Python + can read C on rare occasions, you're golden.

21432379.review: Ah godot engine has been around for a bit im glad it made it to steam its compareable to unity its function  being a tool to create games but is totaly open scource licensed under the extreamely premissive mit license why not  give it a go!

21432281.review:
I do game development since several years. I jumped from one engine to another. With Godot I finally can develop a game on Linux from the start to the end. It's still a young game engine but it has an incredible development pace. I follow its development since last year through GitHub, Facebook and I have to say what others say as a marketing term this game engine really does democratizing game development.
It's open source (MIT License) without strings attached, the main developer(s) listen to the community and welcoms everyone who wants to help in the development, documentation and growth process. 

Some technical notes:
When we have to talk about the technical stuff right now the 3d stuff is really just at the start (although If I take a look around what people often produce with other game engines they could easily do the same with Godot) . One Problem as of now are the shadows and performance in large scenes. That said the 2d part, the custom scripting language, the editor (written in Godot and its GUI itself which proofes the power of it) everything fits so well together. If you come like me from a background with other game engines then you might need some days to fully grasp the concept and its underlying power. But then it makes just click and you see a really powerful game engine that has a lot of potential to become a serious competitor even for commercial grade games. The actual renderer is based on OpenGL (ES) 2.0, which as of right now is perfect for targeting Mobile,Webbrowsers (seems that most WebGL implementation are on par with OpenGL ES 2.0) and of course the desktop. There is an upgrade (and rewrite) planned for the 3d related stuff to OpenGL ES 3.0 which will come with Godot 3.0. In my opinion a lot of people underrate the possibilities with the actual renderer. I'm sure we will soon see some people prooving to be a good alternative to other game engines out there. (And let's not forget it's free to use without big restrictions like a lot of other game engines)

Scene nodes concept:
What I love about Godot is the scene node concept it follows. A lot of engines have some kind of scene node or scene graph based concept. But Godot makes it in a really simple and yet smart way. A scene consists of multiple scene nodes (of all sort of types of nodes for 2d,3d,gui, own defined with modules etc.) . A scene can also contain other scenes within its hierarchy. The keyword here is "instanced scenes", which allows to add scenes in other scenes and people can work on different parts of a big scene without having to fear to break the scene hierarchy, it's really great.  Together with Godots use of source version control friendly file formats this makes for me a great choiche for a collaboration. (Be it a collaboration for a  commercial game or a game for a game jam).  I love the scene node concept as it's main goal is that with one look at the hierarchy you already know where everything is and how it is organized (try that with componend based design where you have to first select objects (and find them first) before seeing which components they contain. 

GUI:
In some simple words: smart, powerful, easy
The editor has everything you need to layout things. GUIs can be 2d on top of 3d content (like we see in every game) or it can be 2d within the 3d content. You need a menu on a display which is made as a 3d model? No problem. With Godot it is easy to set it up. I saw recently a demo where a guy made a 3d game where there was a tv and  game console in a room and you could start playing a 2d game  on that 3d modeled tv. So a game within a game. I know it's also possible with other game engines, but with Godot it's really easy to set these things up, the editor is just easy to use.

Everything can be animated:
With everything I really mean everything! Every kind of property can be animated (so it will be interpolated if the values are float based, set and unset if they are boolean like etc.),  But also function calls can be part of an animation track. Animating is so easy just some clicks and you have a animation ready to play. I made a simplistic day/night animation for instance in just 2-3 minutes lol

Extendibility:
You can write plugins in GDScript (Godots own scripting language which has some similarity with Python but is not Python as it is a scripting language made for game development). 
And you can develop modules in C++. If you had problems integrating C++ libraries in other engines, you might be surprised how easy it is to do it with Godot, thanks to the nice binding functions offered by it. 

My opinion so far:
My opinion is that we are seeing the start of what can become the Blender of the game engines out there. 
If you need a high performance hardcore graphic solution for a game with large scenes then Godot might be the wrong choice rigth now. But it doesn't hurt to try it. It's easy to learn and you don't need to register any account with it. 
I'm happy with it. Btw I used Unity, Unreal and Cryengine among other game engines and while I think that they are far superior in some areas especially in 3d rendering, I also think that they could learn a lot from Godot's simplicity of use and how it organizes some stuff.

As of now you can use it without any doubts for every kind of 2d game, 3d game (if not ultra realistic hardcore graphic is aimed- which will be possible only later on), mobile games  for iOS,Android and even Blackberry. Browsergames (so you can develop 2d and 3d games without needing a plugin).  And it runs on the typical 3 operatin systems for the desktop: Windows, Linux and Mac OS X plus people even made ports for FreeBSD, Haiku (which a lot don't even know it exists) and someone tested it on Raspberry Pi too. This is possible thanks to the permissive license.

I made my choice and I guess I will continue to use it for a long time. I feel that this game engine has potential to become really important. But again as said try it and valuate it if you need more or if it has everything you need right now.

What lacks is still the documentation but it's getting better and better, we'll see

This is in my opinion the best game engine ever made, and it has potential to become even better!

First of all, it is open source, and written in c++, meaning it's easy to extend the engine with your own code and libraries. Secondly, the engine is free and licenced under the permissive MIT licence, meaning you can actually do that and not have to worry about royalties. 21429849.review:
Godot Engine is a true gem for those "in the know". 

Being Open-Source, as an advanced user it allows you maximum flexibility and both Indie and Studio devs can benefit form it's design architecture based on nodes and scenes to create complex game flow. It certainly brings a unique perspective into the game development toolbox.

It's main scripting language is called GDScript which is very similar to Python, but has it's own Keywords to ease setting up several tasks through minimal code. If you are a C++ / LUA / Whatever language user, you can extend Godot with your advanced programming knowledge as well, but you would have to compile from source for that to happen.

However "true" beginner's, beware, if you don't have at least an intermediate foundation in computer programming you will have to study computer programming fundamentals, design patterns and object oriented programming to get the most of it, because this is NOT a DRAG & DROP / ASSET STORE program.  This is a professional tool for creating powerful Indie & A(AA) games alike, not a multiplayer creator sandbox with limited scope.

Making games is hard work, but when tamed, Godot can be an incredible helper or standalone tool for developing your own unique games.

p.s. Godot has been used to make commercial games.
p.s.2. Godot is not Unreal Engine 4, Unity, Construct2, or Roblox. Please stop thinking about how it doesn't compare.

21428454.review:
Mnohé OS enginy trpí pomalým vývojem, jsou pořád silně rozpracované a nejsou vhodné pro seriózní použití. Godot je ovšem jiný a po roce používání mohu říct, že podobným problémem netrpí. I když byly zdrojové kódy uvolněny relativně nedávno, engine byl šest let používán jako interní nástroj studia OKAM a za tu dobu si jeho architektura prošla několika změnami. Zvládl tedy zatěžkávací test a nejedná se o žádný hurá projekt, který bude použitelný možná až za několik let. Mezi 2D enginy nemá konkurenci. Jeho 3D renderer je ovšem pozadu (platí pro verzi 2.0) a pokud nehodláte použít silnou grafickou stylizaci, poohlédněte se jinde. Nebo počkejte na verzi 3.0, která přinese úplně nový 3D backend.

Za opravdu silnou stránku enginu považuji jeho přístupnost. Programovat můžete dobře, ale jakmile je editor nepřehledný a zahltí vás velkým množstvím informací, snadno se v něm ztratíte. Godot je velmi přehledný díky systému, jakým se hra tvoří. Na nováčky je shovívavý a zkušenější mohou velmi rychle uvádět do chodu své prototypy. Je ale také dostatečně propracovaný, takže až budete potřebovat pokročilé funkce, pravděpodobně je zde naleznete.

Systém, co jsem zmiňoval, je systém scén. Ta může být cokoliv. Level, charakter, inventář, nahrávací obrazovka, generátor dungeonu, GUI. Může to být jakýkoliv celek, co si dovedete představit. Scény pak vytváříte z uzlů tím, že je skládáte do stromové struktury. Uzel je základní stavební jednotka – objekt vykonávající specifickou funkci, který vývojáři zpřístupňuje funkce, pomocí kterých je ovládá ve skriptu (pro programátory: uzel je třída, ze které vytváříte objekty - scéna je strom objektů).

Poslední důležitou součástí Godotu je skriptovací jazyk GDScript, který respektuje OOP a velmi se podobá Pythonu. Je dynamicky psaný a má podobnou syntaxi. Velmi rychle jsem si ho osvojil, i když mám mnohem raději staticky psaný jazyk. Oproti C++ je pomalejší (protože je sám napsán v C++), ale kritické části hry můžete přepsat do C++. Sám editor obsahuje poměrně proracovaný editor GDScriptu, který podporuje automatické doplňování. Kód pak můžete odladit integrovaným debuggerem.

I když Godot patří ke špičce mezi open source enginy a je konkurence schopný i mezi komerčními, má své nedostatky. 2D engine patří mezi ty pokročilejší, ale ten 3D je tak generaci až dvě pozadu. Věřím tomu, že se silnou stylizací můžete vytvořit hezkou 3D hru, ale na technologickou špičku se Godot dívá z velké dálky. Budoucnost enginu však vypadá velmi dobře. Největším milníkem má být kompletní přepsání 3D renderu, který by tak měl konečně dohnat dobu. Alespoň já pak nebudu vidět důvod, proč se vůbec poohlížet po jiném herním enginu.

21423234.review:
Amazing game engine with a huge set of tools. Its strength lies in the 2D engine. Once you are familiar with it, prototyping a 2D games is quick and easy.
The 3D editor has not received much love recently, and the renderer is stuck with GLES2, but it's planned to implement GLES3 for 3.0 (hopefully late 2016 or earlier 2017). Of course, this doesn't prevent anyone from creating great looking 3D games already.
The engine comes with a built-in script editor and debugger. The animation system is another of its strengths, allowing to animate almost everything.
In Godot you can instance scenes into scenes (this is the main difference over engines that use prefabs). This is a powerful tool for organizing your porjects.
The main fear you can find is the custom scripting language. GDScript is similar to Python, and new users tend to dislike learning a new language. But once you get used to it, you will understand the decision over other existing languages. GDScript and its debugger are really well integrated with the engine, making our life easier. If some parts of your code need better performance, you can write them as modules in C++.
The community is huge and very helpful. You can ask questions on the Q&A site, reddit, the facebook group, or the IRC channel. There are many community made plugins, modules and game examples (checkout [b]awesome-godot[/b] on GitHub), and hopefully we can get a asset sharing site soon.
Oh! Did I mention the engine is completely free and open source?

I've been using Godot for a long time already (since it first got released), so now it's great to see it here on steam as well.

I've used a lot of game engines, both paid and 'free' (free as in you do not pay - but licenses \ royalty included), and I also have been using other game engines like godot (with editor included) ( Maratis3d, leadwerks, unity, unreal).
but I always come back to Godot, the reasons are many, but mainly for me - it's fully free, advanced, easy to learn, no royalties, no cost. Works great on both windows and Linux.

Many people makes the GDScript a issue, but honestly it's not, if you are into game development and serious about it then you take your time to learn it, it's just like learning many other tool.
And if you want you can also use the engine through c++ API.

Godot has all the tools you need to develop your game, and is getting better every  day.
Physics, light baking, 2D\3D games, what ever you need it for.
Auto detects when meshes has been updated and reloads them when needed, is also a nice feature.
Many many things makes Godot a great experience to work with.

Documentations is great, easy to find what you need, comunity is also very helpful.
And the engine comes with a lot of great demo projects to get you started.
Also - it's easy to compile the whole engine from source if that's your thing.

So - do I think you should use it? Absolutely YES!

21420928.review:
A very interesting engine, also one of the few that run natively on Linux for both exporting and editing.

It can be a bit unusual to get started with, but once you figure it out, it allows for very rapid progress. The engine works with "scenes", which are collections of "nodes". Such nodes are basic game entities like sprites, GUI controls or physics bodies, or more complex ones like audio output, cameras and such.
Every node can be given its own scripting in the engine's native language, known as gdscript. Gdscript itself is very easy to learn, and even easier if you are familiar with the python language. While it's a bit of a bummer to not be able to use, for example, Lua, the language barely takes an evening to learn if you can already code, and shouldn't take much longer if you don't. The editor contains a very competent code editor with all the bells and whistles, from bracket highlighting to autocompletion, which helps a lot.

Once your scene is set up, you can import it into other scenes, creating more complex scenes that you can alter dynamically with relative ease. For example, you can create a scene containing the HUD for your game, then import it into your main game scene, or custom widgets that you can include in said HUD. All very hassle-free.
The node system is also very good to write quick interfaces for debugging/development tools, saving huge amounts of time and allowing to provide suchs tools as modding tools once the game is shipped.

Once your game is complete, it's easy to export it to various systems, including the usual 3 (Win/Mac/Lin), Android and  HTML5 for in-browser games. It even allows exporting to...blackberry, for some reason.
The process is quick and simple, only requiring a few clicks, and includes various options allowing from open-sourced games to single-binary distributions, or even encrypted data.

Now, I have been using the engine for a while, and it's really solid for 2D games. And while it might not be as powerful as others for 3D games, it's competent enough if you use the features creatively. The engine is being developed at a rapid pace, and it gains features and improvements at a good rate, so if you find it lacking in some aspects, it might have just what you need for the next version.

Other interesting features include a very powerful animation system that allows keying almost every single element in your scene, allowing for easy cutscenes, skeleton-based animations and other cool visual effects. It also allows importing most common data formats used in development, international fonts, built-in localization features and other goodies, allowing for very easy prototyping or fully featured games. It also has a live editing feature allowing to change elements of your game in real time from the editor while the game is running, which can accelerate debugging and testing stuff like enemy logic in the project. A huge time saver.
The entire engine's source and issue tracker are hosted over at GitHub, allowing to easily keep track with progress, report bugs or collaborate with the project, which helps refining it further. The editor is also surprisingly stable, and I haven't encountered a single crash or data loss in months of use, even using bleeding-edge daily builds. It's also very easy to build in all systems, if you prefer to keep up with every single commit to the codebase or modify it to implement advanced features or alter core behaviors directly.

As the main flaw, while it has a number of step-by-step tutorials, some elements aren't completely covered by the available documentation, but the tutorials should be able to cover most basics, and the in-editor help covers almost all the classes and nodes without having to keep switching to a browser window for reference. There are a number of included demos which also can help giving you hints on how to proceed. Documentation is being worked on actively, so this flaw might be addressed sooner than later.

21418279.review:
This is my first and only game engine, but my experience has been a great one!

I hadn't worked on a game for a few years, so I started looking around at engines. I was considering Unity, and reached out to them to see if they would ever release a Linux editor. They replied to my email telling me to just run Windows and export my games to Linux. No, thanks! So, I put my plans on the backburner...

...but not for long! A few days after my disappointing email exchange with Unity, news of plans to open-source Godot started making the rounds. I excitedly fired off an email to Juan Linietsky, who had offered to send out a pre-release to people wishing to try it and point out any immediate issues they found. Within a day, I was up and experimenting with an already-impressive, free, soon-to-be-open, game creation tool.

Previous to using Godot, I would make my game projects from scratch in C/C++ with SDL libraries. Godot was much different. It was kinda love at first tinker.

I admit that I was initially hesitant to invest much time into Godot because of the custom script language, GDScript. It's very similar to Python (which I had never used). However, after diving in, I found it to be very clear, clean, and fast. It's even easier since the syntax hinting and autocompletion were introduced. I see a lot of complaints around the web about how it should use C# or Lua or whatever, but I don't see the need. That being said, the engine is completely free and open-source (MIT license), so feel free to whip one up and contribute it so everyone else can use it, too. Or just keep complaining. Your call.

Speaking of contributing, the codebase is quite nice, even for people with modest C++ skills like myself. I was able to make a few meaningful contributions over the years, and hope to do more if/when I can. But this new release is a huge leap forward compared to a year ago. I think any of my minor complaints have been alleviated!

For 2D games, this engine is fantastic. 3D is limited to GLES2 right now, but a GLES3/3.1 rendering backend is planned for the 3.0 release, so that will bring over many capabilities that even the most demanding 3D developer will require. That being said, the GLES2 backend that already exists is capable of putting out some nice-looking pixels.

You can export your games to a variety of platforms with just a few clicks, and I've had no issues with that process so far (though i've no Apple devices to actually do any testing of those versions).

There are a lot of great things about Godot, and it's hard to list them all here (pointless, too, since it's going to continue evolving closer and closer towards perfection). It's free though, so you can jump in and try it out yourself.
